title: Good
pros: ⭐⭐ good so far as I've been working
cons: Left the company much earlier

title: A Masterclass in Dysfunction — Enter at Your Own Risk
pros: If you're seeking a fast-track to burnout and a front-row seat to toxic leadership, this is the place for you. Micromanagement? Check. Gaslighting? Absolutely. Supervisors who double as textbook narcissists? Say no more. If being ignored when you ask for support and working with disengaged teammates sounds like your ideal environment, you’ll feel right at home. Also, if you're passionate about watching a company celebrate record profits while rewarding employees with the bare minimum — congratulations, you’ve found your match.
cons: The work environment is deeply unsupportive. Requests for help or clarification are often met with silence or condescension. Communication is poor, and collaboration feels more like survival. Leadership is out of touch with employee realities, and concerns are routinely dismissed or downplayed. There is little to no career development, and burnout is treated as a badge of honor rather than a red flag. Raises and recognition are scarce, despite the company’s financial success.

title: Dishonest & Cowardly Organization
pros: Attempts at employee engagement were great to see.
cons: Poor working conditions. Building was old and had dead animals in bathrooms that were never cleaned. Organization is too siloed and can’t function together. Any attempt to work inter-departmentaly was met with angst and resistance. Asked to perform tasks that were borderline illegal and manipulate legal documents to avoid “attention”. Leaders are making business decisions motivated by racial prejudice instead of business models. Was nervous to travel for business with others due to alcohol abuse while on company time.

pros: Great collaborative team that works well together.
cons: Very corporate. There are numerous hoops to jump through to complete tasks.

title: Accounting Department - Unrealistic work hours & expectations
pros: Good insurance Wellness perks Pizza parties
cons: Gradually phasing out WFH & back to predominantly in office. People are promoted with zero management, people skills or training. When questioned they state training is not in the budget. These promoted individuals then work around the clock 7 days a week making all work expectations ridiculous for others. You can not take off except when they feel it’s in line with their schedules. 2-3 weeks is are blacked out per quarter. The Accounting department is expected to work many weekends, Juneteenth, 4th of July, Christmas, New Years with no days given back as compensation. You are fortunate to take the vacation days you have due to workload & the fact no one does ANY work for you while you are out of the office. Spring break with your kids, you are not allowed to take off. It is also a blacked out time period. You also need to plan to be in the office as well, so then plan for childcare during that time. Great place to work if you have nothing else in your life outside of work. It is not a good place for anyone with a kids, because they really do not care.

title: Love this company
pros:
-hybrid
-not micromanaged
-team culture
-company culture
cons:
-no room for growth
-complicated systems to learn

title: Overworked
pros: Great team to be a part of.
cons: Management doesn’t provide much help

title: leasing
pros: Well run company and CEO
cons: Making us come in three days opposed to 2 days

title: Great Company, Amazing Company
pros: Balanced work life, Knowledgeable and great place to learn/work
cons: None that come to mind

pros: Good work environment, Helpful teammates & co-workers from other departments
cons: Pay vs Economy, additional income is needed Hybrid should be reduced to 1day instead of 2 days

title: Bad processes
pros: They have scale which let's them do things that other real estate operators can't.
cons: Processes are not consistent across the company. If you ask 5 people the same question, you'll get 5 different answers which will all be wrong. Any documentation or training material you can find will be outdated - covering systems that haven't been in place for more than 5 years. Every training document will be either 70 pages or multiple 2 hour recordings. This makes everything needlessly complicated. Tenure is very long here which means that most people aren't open to changing the way they do things.

title: Great Company
pros: Management team is fantastic and care about their employees.
cons: There were not any negatives about the position. On a personal level my commute was long but that was my decision.

title: Good company to work for
pros: Friendly, team oriented, organized, good benefits
cons: Stressful, micromanaged, rigid, gossipy, overworked

title: Kimco
pros: Work from home hybrid (don't know if they still do this). Wonderful supervisors who are willing to help you when you need it
cons: Upper management is a different story

title: Kimco Realty
pros: Great people, some offices have more activity which can help boost moral, nice benefits.
cons: Process overload, need to improve onboarding techniques

title: Great company
pros: Company and team were great to work with. Experienced team. Pay was generous for the role.
cons: The role was duplicative and required a lot of manual data entry

title: Salary
pros: The company had good benefits.
cons: I can't think of any cons.

title: Pretty Good
pros: Small business feel. Upper management is very good at listening and trying to help. Work from home 3 days a week.
cons: Middle management are good accountants. They're not good managers.

title: Good with some bad
pros: Hybrid work environment that works foe everyone.
cons: Gossiping and rumor mill amongst management. Not good management skills .

title: Property Management
pros: Great team and great benefits
cons: Subpar pay and poor leadership

title: Great employer
pros: Stable job and friendly environment
cons: Hard to move up laddle

title: Disappointing
pros: Decent health benefits and PTO package
cons: No summer Fridays. Burnout employees, additional responsibilities without staff increase. Pay not industry standards. Do not attempt to retain employees, they prefer to see them leave than make changes. Expect working on weekends without additional compensation or time off. HR/execs threaten return to office when they feel employees not producing.

title: Great benefits
pros: Always busy time goes by fast
cons: Disconnected from corporate since it’s located in Ny

title: Fantastic company!
pros: Community Teamwork Good attitude Hybrid work from home
cons: Overall pleased with the company

title: Ridiculous Experience
pros: One star for the paycheck every two weeks.
cons: In a nutshell: Management: Inappropriate, Biased, Condescending and Extra Co-workers: Fake, Pretentious, Disrespectful Company: Woke, Hypocritical, Insincere

title: Great place to work!
pros: Great work life balance, benefits, people.
cons: You are very busy most of the time.

title: Solid workplace
pros: Hybrid work model, Good training
cons: Average pay, not very competitive

title: Long term investment worth it
pros: Good people, procedures in place to protect employees and management, good benefits, good career skills are taught here
cons: Many small rules to follow, nit picking, leadership doesn't always have control over middle management supervision

title: Great company!
pros: My boss was the best boss I’ve ever had. She was a gem and made my decision to leave so hard.
cons: None that I can think of.

title: Not too Satisfied
pros: One of the PROs is the benefits package.
cons: - The company provides New hires with a mentor but not everyone is good at mentoring/training. they should have a designated person trained to be able to train New hires. This way the company can benefit from the new hire and ultimately bring the company success. - The company is trying to fit too many roles into one role - Managers & supervisors are micro-managing, instead of working collectively with their team members to get the work done. At the end of the day, aren't we on the same team trying to recover the company's money? Also, they encourage to ask questions but then criticize you if you happen to ask the same question a few weeks later. - The review process does not need to be in written form; which is a major CON because in today's society it's best to have things in writing, especially when it comes to job performance. - The company should have a designated HR person for each dept. or have their HR personnel outsourced, because once you are hired you never hear from HR again.

title: great company to work for
pros: great benefits and most employees work remotely
cons: No downside for working with Kimco

title: Salary
pros: Not the best place to work.
cons: Very poor management and leadership

title: Good Company
pros: Good work life balance, good benefits
cons: Corporate vibe, promotions are based on tenure

title: Great Company
pros: It was great to work in this company
cons: Should have more staff in the office

title: Good
pros: Flexible, learned a lot, very structured
cons: Not much room for growth

title: Tenant Account Analyst
pros: PTO, health program, corporate functions, bagel Fridays, Christmas party, large firm, great heath benefits, promotes wellness, flexible accommodations.
cons: HR turns a blind eye to the unethical conducts in the office, cursing, insulting employees etc. Position will always be busy, but there will be no end result. They just need another initial or signature next to a note to pass liability. If you play by their rules, you can bite the bullet and find growth in this firm. If you have any pride, this specific department is not for you, there is favoritism, lack of professionalism and management needs learn how to manage. If you know what your doing, good, if you don't, forget asking for help. The departments are never on the same page and fingers are pointed at the TAA. This position is the garbage disposal of the company. All work that other department's don't want to touch, gets pushed on to the TAA in addition to the 6 other positions conglomerated into this one "hybrid" position. It's entry level pay, but you are an auditor, financial analyst, lease analyst, collections agent, paralegal etc...in one. Can't say much for the company but from my experience, I regretted stepping foot in the door.

title: Asset Management
pros: Dynamic, innovative, humble. Land of opportunity. When you work for Kimco, there really are no limits. If you have a work ethic and want to learn, you can learn any aspect of commercial real estate that you have an interest in. Every year something new and innovative is happening and you have a chance to be a part of it. Generous time off, opportunities to volunteer, team building events, education reimbursement, scholarships for children of employees-- they really care about retaining employees.
cons: It is what you make of it. If you truly aren't happy here, you can make a change and still find a niche that motivates you - within Kimco. It really is an organization that wants you to be successful.

title: WARNING: Avoid any interaction with Corporate Accounting
pros: Regional Directors and Vice Presidents are great people to work with. Company benefits are good although every year they give it a hair cut.
cons: Accounting software CTI is extremely old, you'll never use this version of Yardi anywhere else in your career. CFO's mantra of having his "All-Stars" and "Blockers and Tacklers" in his staff creates a horrible unprofessional environment. Regional office staff tries to avoid corporate accounting managers at all costs.

title: The axe is always ready to fall.....
pros: Benefits are still ok even though they've decreased in recent years.
cons: They recently contracted with Accenture to outsource many of its administration functions to India. There have been massive layoffs and it is expected, (although management denies it) that there will be more. The level of corporate greed is astounding. The company is doing better than they have in many years but it still needs more profits. There is no loyalty to long term employees and no recognition of the hard work they've done. Morale is non existent and that's OK with the current team of executives as long as the stock price continues to climb. Workers salaries are always capped. They've converted to majority of the workforce to exempt status, so there is no pay for overtime. People who remain are like zombies, overworked, underpaid and constantly under threat.

title: Kimco is a nice place to work
pros: They offer great benefits to full time employees. Good medical, dental and other perks. Medical insurance here is well subsidized by the company. Your payments for your premiums are low-even for the whole family
cons: The salary could be higher. I believe there should be more opportunity to advance in the company. You usually start off with the company as a temporary employee, then hope that there is an opening to move to permanent status. When you're a full time employee, you are then eligible to receive a wide variety of benefits. The New York employees seem to have more perks than the other branches across the country.

title: If your a woman don't work here
pros: Decent benefits, bagel Friday's, used to have a Christmas bonus, used to give stock, used to care about employees... Don't have any.
cons: Management will lie to you and tell you they appreciate your hard work and take credit for it to advance themselves. If your a man and a drinking buddy you will do fine here. They seem to be promoted even though they are unqualified. Forget working hard because it doesn't matter, if your a man who doesn't produce and doesn't show up, you will be promoted! Also it's okay if your a man and crack race, religious or other offensive jokes, so long as your the drinking buddy, career advancement awaits you! Last 3 years it really went to garbage!

title: Bad Manager
pros: Good benefits, generous PTO, stock payout, and strong c-executives.
cons: Pay is not competitive. Regional, internal promotions are not based on hard work or dedication, but based on who you are friends with.

title: Lease Administrator
pros: Great place to learn real estate . Great staff. Staff is family oriented. Good benefits.
cons: Upper management sucks. You have to practically kiss butt and watch other lips in the meantime. They use to have a great management staff until they laid them off and replaced them. Go figure. The older management staff helped promote and gave opportunity for advancement. The current management team sucks.

title: Good company - growth is limited
pros: Great benefits, stock options, vacation time, and strong c-suite executives Middle management can be hit or miss depending on who you report to (I had a great manager but know of others not so great) A progressive company always looking to improve and willing to take suggestions from all employees
cons: Salary - Kimco has very high standards for its employees and the rate of pay does not always match up with the work expectations Lack of growth - There are a lot of long term employees 10+ years which is good for the company but makes it difficult for others to grow

title: Kimco Realty
pros: Great company and Culture, but it all depends on which department you work for.
cons: Lease administration was terrible. Managers assume that you know the accounting systems like the back of your hand from the day you start working. No formal training from managers and/or corporate. You are left to twiddle you thumbs and "figure it out" on your own. Rather than have the managers guide you to the answer to save the company time and manpower they scold you for not knowing the answer.

title: Had an overall positive experience!
pros: Great Benefits, 401(k) match, generous PTO, Solid mentors, great working environment with friendly group environment. Very family friendly. I worked at Kimco and I had a great working experience overall! Did accounting & analysis for various mall properties. I've been told that your experience at Kimco highly depends on what group and bosses you end up with, so do your homework before applying, if you can.
cons: Repetitive workload, deadline oriented, Hard to earn advancement (People tend to stay in the same roles for years). Sometimes tough to see eye to eye with management.

title: The current PFA management team (excluding Michelle Shaver) needs to be replaced
pros: Direct managers genuinely care about the employees and are fantastic to work with. The company is very flexible with employee work schedules and offers generous PTO/sick time packages. Year-end bonuses are around 10% of annual salary plus every February employees are given a stock option payout of several thousand dollars. Kimco offers tuition reimbursement up to $6K annually and matches 401k contributions up to 5%. Insurance benefits are better than most, and they offer optional flex spending accounts for healthcare and dependent care as well.
cons: Most (if not all) managers above one's direct manager are very difficult to work underneath. Many tend to micromanage and want to have their hands in every minute detail, yet when something important is needed from them, they either do not respond or it takes weeks/months to get an answer that should have taken 10 minutes. Upper management makes rash decisions about employees based upon limited observations and does not listen to their management team for input. The work currently being performed by the former Lease Administrator/Analyst position is a joke. Anyone with a brain will be bored to death. I really want to love this company and love the job. Kimco truly is a great company with great potential. It's the current management team that has ruined the PFA team. I will say the current management team has implemented some good changes on the accounting side, but the changes made to the lease administration and collections teams have had a negative impact.

title: Inside Kimco
pros: It varies by department, but if you're a hardworker, there is always work to do. Good 401k match and decent health benefits. I learned many new skills here. The founder works hard and he has shown to be intelligent, hard working and respectful.
cons: This became an uncomfortable, grueling place to go back to everyday. Some employees have favor and special accommodations when others dont. Communication is unclear. Many responsible employees are under higher demands and expectations including completing the work of several others with no added pay. The appreciation and respect was not usually given for consistent jobs well done. Common courtesy was scarce. In many areas, management is too top heavy. For example, 3 in management for a staff of 3-4 employees. Micro-managing is very common. The management drives workers into the ground and often takes sole credit for the accomplishments. For years, a department was overloaded with deadlines and pressure and it seemed they wanted robots instead if humans to complete the work. The company speaks of doing well to the investors but departmentally , employees are pushed relentlessly and not always acknowledged, appreciated or fairly compensated. Morale is low. Gradually, the benefit package was decreased. HR implemented a program to encourage getting more steps in each day. This was a refreshing concept until managers showed disdain for those who stepped away from their desk to take a short walking break. Senior management has a boys club vibe. Many employees are fully overloaded with deadlines and tasks. Frequent management changes at different levels caused repeated transition and confusion. Annual layoffs trigger a lingering fear for dedicated employees.

title: Lease Administrator
pros: The company is great to work for. They have the right idea for its employees but not having the right management staff discredits this company.
cons: Management choice is poor as they go by favortism. The managers they've chosen are loud, rude and inconsiderate. It's their way or no way. Management gossips about employees business to one another. Some managers are micro managers and are very controlling.

title: Accounts payable
pros: Free coffee. Free breakfast every friday.
cons: This place is horrible to work for. So many rude people here. They never smile and act like saying hi will kill them. They dont like to help new people .They give too much work and do away with certain positions to give more work to other departments. Many people who have started here years ago still work here so dont think a position will open up for you because it wont. Such a horrible place to work!!!! Stay away

title: If you want to get ahead, do not work here.
pros: Medical benefits are excellent. If you want to work on Long Island, centrally located. Good first job for college graduates.
cons: This company does not encourage any thinking whatsoever. Career micromanagers run this company. Follow the policies and procedures manuals (1000 + pages) and you will survive. Pay is poor. Do not think "outside of the box" it will not work in this company.

title: Poor Management
pros: Love the company and staff. Great place to work.
cons: There should be systems in place that everyone has to follow, including Management.

title: Decent if you like the daily grind.
pros: Most people in lower management are nice. Convenient area. Good salary and benefits. The average employee is in and out 9am-5pm.
cons: Senior management is hardly approachable if you're near the bottom of the totem pole. Professionalism is in question at all levels. While they do promote to fill vacant upper level spots, they promote largely based on seniority instead of competence. Senior management seems to not care at all about the people who make the company tick such as the Accounts Receivable/Payable Departments.

title: Generally acceptable
pros: I got to work on some big projects in a very upscale environment.
cons: Kimco purchased Suburban Square right before the market crashed. They treated he property like the strip malls they own all over the country rather than the historic destination property it is. I went out on disability for shoulder and back issues. That part was my fault. I tried harder than I should have.

title: Good compensation but very political in upper management
pros: Compensation is good and room to work independently. The brand recognition of the company helps working with external stakeholders.
cons: Political fighting in upper management and nepotism. The company feels like a family business despite being listed on NYSE.

title: Horrible work environment
pros: Compensation and benefits are good
cons: Don't work here if you want to work your way up in the ranks. Advancement is based on length of employment not job performance or ability. Everything is micro managed, creative thinking is not encouraged. Used to be a big company with a small company / family feel but with the current corporate management team it has been turned into a drone factory for accountants. There is no place for you without a degree in finance. Morale is at an all time low and it will probably get worse because they are making major changes to operations.

title: Adapts Quickly to Life
pros: Excellent streamlined organization with quality management. They did truly take COVID seriously for both employees and tenants I am very impressed how much help they were will to give whether it was for rent or work from home
cons: High turnover in lower position employees make learning tough The lower your position, you are less and less a person and more a robot to spit work out

title: Could be so much more
pros: You’ll never be short of work…
cons: Sadly, most of the staff is overworked and UNDER appreciated. Positions are eliminated and then “absorbed” rather than replaced…I watched many committed, hardworking people get burned out and frustrated. Its sad really. It could be a fabulous company.

title: EXCELLENT COMPANY!!
pros: One of the largest REITs, publicly-traded, long track record of success, majority of associates have been here for long periods of time, dynamic management and leadership, welcoming human resources, brand new office with new tech
cons: None unless you consider commuting to Long Island a con- majority of associates live on Long Island so the location makes sense

title: Great place to work with a strong entrepreneurial culture
pros: A very supportive culture with great people, which makes the everyday that much more enjoyable. There is a strong emphasis on teamwork and management always encourages the suggestion of new ideas to improve day to day operations.
cons: Not much to say here. It's a wonderful and stimulating place to work, they promote from within and the size of the portfolio ensures that you are always faced with new opportunities.

title: Amazing Company
pros: Amazing benefits, wonderful upper management and executives, and always innovating and improving with new technology.
cons: Large amount of work to be done and even though they brought in new technology to make life easier, they will do occasional layoffs and reallocate responsibilities leading to continued increased workload for employees.

title: Great company, tough role
pros: Strong company culture, collaborative, competitive pay, progressive team, great onboarding for HR & widely used systems.
cons: Very demanding, “always on” hustle culture, work is heavily criticized, processes change often and with little notice to team, insufficient training for department specific systems and procedures

title: Solid company
pros: Fair pay, good benefits and the company likes to promote from within.
cons: Communication isn't great despite the fact that the company THINKS they do a great job. And they have let many very talented employees leave without attempting to make it worthwhile to stay. Most recently alot of jobs have been "eliminated" or changed and then they dont replace those people...those jobs just get "absorbed" by those of us still here.

title: Great company
pros: Cares for employees and very inclusive. Great PTO and 401k match. Flex WFH and in office.
cons: Workload can be very high at times, procedures/policy changes occur frequently and can be confusing. Organization siloed from other departments and communication can be tough between departments.

title: Some good...some bad
pros: Quarterly skill path classes, teams outings, generous PTO and sick days.
cons: Lack of skilled management, corporate politics, outsourcing our jobs to India, No chance to promote, although undeserving people get promoted to management without required to take management skill courses. Lots and Lots of favortism.

title: This has been the best atomosphere I've ever had the pleasure to work in
pros: Professional co-workers, modern technology, well stocked with supplies and equipment, coffee and bagels, staff appreciation events
cons: Paper work heavy, too many people involved in every transaction, new hires start as temps and wait months, years to be hired with benefits.

title: I wasted over a year of my life working here...
pros: Bragging rights to say you work for a publicly traded company. My annual bonus was 7.5% of my salary which is better than average. They pay 90% of employee health insurance and it is a good plan.
cons: Pay is below industry standard. Work load is unrealistic. As a PM you are responsible for 12 shopping centers. This should be a team of 5, but they expect one person to do it all with one (low paid) assistant. They expect you to use the company issued Blackberry (yuk!) and be on call 24-7. Tenants hate Kimco because there is no customer service. Tenants call and yell at you because they are frustrated and upset. I never received an annual employee review, no increase in salary, no possibility to move up the ladder, no mentors. When you get hired, they say they reimburse for education, but my manager refused to authorize reimbursement for a work related class. If you get a "title change" there is no pay with the increase in work load. The computer data systems are antiquated. Nothing is linked together. You have to look 5 places for information to fill out a form. The systems and procedures bog you down from doing your job. If you make a mistake there is someone from the Corporate office who will call and yell at you and make you feel terrible. Why this rude person still works for Kimco is unacceptable! I found Kimco to be a negative environment where people were burned out and/ or not happy.

title: Great Company!
pros: Stable, great ethics and positive work environment. Associates all work hard and are very responsive and helpful. Good benefits and supports community service.
cons: Office is located well off the highway and not central to anything so commute can be a bit difficuls and takes time out of the day.

title: Brutal !!!!
pros: Free coffee and good benefits. There really aren't many pros that I can currently think of. I am sure the company overall isn't that bad however the department where I was, really needs a drastic change.
cons: No morale, micromanagers, not a team building environment at all. Lack of support for someone who is new, Co-workers love throwing you under the bus, Lack of creativity (at least in the department I was in.) You are just another robot who really doesn't have much of a say.

title: Overall great company to work for
pros: CEO is amazing and truly wants to do right by all employees. Paid Holidays are amazing Easy to communicate to supervisors
cons: Pay could be better for the amount of work that is required of employees Everything is always deemed important and urgent but then could receive another email that it's no longer needed or required.

title: Great Company!
pros: If you like to be part of a dynamic team, this is the place for you. Great people, great projects, lots of opportunity to share ideas.
cons: Office is located well off the highway, so this adds time to the commute.

title: Good company to work with
pros: Great salary and office environment. The bonuses are ok according to performance. Is an international company with operations in Mexico y South America.
cons: Not good opportunities to grow, the accounting system is simple and hard to work with partners to get information for qtr closing.

title: Property Assistant
pros: Company does not wait for you to accrue your PTO, you can use prior to YE.
cons: A great deal of paperwork to muddle through on day to day basis. This effects productivity.

title: Too many personal changes that affect the moral of the team.
pros: CEO truly listens to the employees. Responds will to to all inquires.
cons: Regional leadership lacks communication to the team. You will never know if you are doing a good job or a bad until its too late.

title: Terrible Work Enviornment
pros: Great benefits package and bagels on Friday morning.
cons: The department was micromanaged and moral was low. They are hiring people with little to no experience to run large portfolios thus putting a strain on the entire department. You would think a large publically traded company would hire people that have many years of experience to manage their assets and mentor property management assistants. Upper management uses the support staff as scapegoats.

title: Analyst
pros: Great benefits and generous paid time off
cons: No room for advancement, no/few minorities in management positions in New Hyde Park, opportunities are provided based on nepotism

title: Great Company to Work For
pros: -Great benefits -Very flexible -Company does a lot for their employees and besides the benefits, they provide free different types of training, holiday parties, picnics, etc.
cons: miscommunication within departments; maternity leave is not what it used to be.

title: Kimco
pros: The co-workers and managers are the best!
cons: They don't promote someone to be a mngr within the dept, they instead put employees from another dept who don't know anything about the dept/position

title: Senior Accountant
pros: Good health benefits. Great immediate supervisor who mentors and teaches.
cons: Little room for advancement and uncompetitive salaries. Promotions given don't come with increase in salary.

title: Financial Operations
pros: good benefits. overly casual atmosphere. management is never in the office and nobody seems to work on Fridays.
cons: corporate micro-management, regional leader can be elitist, sexists and comments inappropriate. favoritism is abundant and if you are not management you are not treated equally. moral is poor

title: Great people to work with!
pros: Great people, great benefits, upward mobility, remote atmosphere.
cons: Processes are overwhelming and need to be streamlined.

title: Striving to change but struggling
pros: Community involvement is superb! Company embraces culture and creates family oriented opportunities.
cons: Tenured and seasoned procedures with seasoned head departments unwilling to embrace the new culture.

title: Great Job - Poor Middle Management
pros: The work is stimulating and rewarding. Good benefits and pay is above average
cons: Middle management is very weak. Company structured by region. Regional Presidents are not very strong especially in the West.

title: Learned a lot
pros: Learned a lot in the accounting department. Great supervisors at the time. Long hours but everyone was "in it together"
cons: Base pay and subsequent raises were pretty low.

title: Overall great management
pros: Holiday pay Work Environment - Family mentality
cons: Gross Pay starting off is low Workload can be overwhelming

title: Mile a minute
pros: Job stability and security- always moving towards growth.
cons: Be prepared to move a mile a minute- get bogged down in bureaucracy - and then back to a mile a minute.

title: Lease Administration
pros: Great company, great benefits, great bunch of people
cons: Office closing, no summary hours, no work from home

title: Good place to work
pros: great team, culture and work life balance
cons: very hard to move up and get promoted. people here are deeply rooted and will rarely leave.

title: Property Assistant
pros: - Good hours - Heavy workload - Ability to learn from some seasoned professionals
cons: - Micromanagement - No room for growth

title: Great Company but..
pros: Great company led by a true leader.
cons: Equality and PC has turned the Company sideways to promote folks who truly don’t deserve to be promoted.

title: It was ok but management fails to recognize good talent
pros: Good benefit package but little room for growth
cons: Long hours of work with little recognition

title: Director of Real Estate
pros: Great company with great benefits! Stable company with little politicking.
cons: Difficult to advance to senior management.

title: Good company overall
pros: The New Hyde Park office was a great office to work for and offered opportunities for advancement.
cons: The Lutherville office seemed to lack the continuity of the corporate office.

title: Solid business with good leadership
pros: invest in employees long term
cons: if they have invested in your boss, who isn't so great, your boss will still be around for a while

title: Good Work Environment
pros: Tight family environment, management knows the direction they want to go but can be sidetracked
